I think you 're thinking about it the wrong way . So , light goes fast , yeah ? It goes so fast that it was n't until relatively recently that people found out that it was n't instantaneous . But once we discovered that it had a finite speed , people began trying to measure it . And someone did measure light eventually , and everything was fine . And then someone found out that light was actually a wave . Light is actually just a travelling disturbance in an electrical field , just like ripples on a pond are a disturbance on the surface of water . Well , if it 's a wave , then it has to be travelling through something , right ?

However , we also knew that it could travel through seemingly empty space , and so whatever it was travelling had to fill the entire universe , and had to be extremely light , as it could n't be detected gravitationally . People called this mysterious substance the ' luminiferous aether ' . And then we also discovered that the Earth is orbiting around the Sun . Well , if the Earth is moving through this mysterious substance that fills the universe , then it follows that at different times of the year , we are travelling through the aether at different velocities . This means that we should be able to measure a different speed of light in the spring compared to in the fall . Except

that we did n't . We found that no matter where the Earth was moving , we always got the same value for the speed of light . As scientific instruments got more sophisticated , it became increasingly apparent that no matter how fast or in what direction you were moving , you would always measure light to be travelling the same speed . This was a mind - boggling result , and let me tell you why . Imagine that you are biking down a road at 10 miles an hour , and you pass a friend that is waiting for a bus . All of a sudden , a car zooms past you . Your friend , who is sitting still , measures the car to

be going 40 miles per hour . You measure see the car to be going at 30 miles per hour * relative to yourself * , since you were already moving . Now , instead of a car , lets say a beam of light flies past you , because the neighbor 's kid is playing with a laser pointer . Your friend measures the beam of light to be travelling at a speed , which we 'll call C. Naively , you would expect yourself to measure this beam of light travelling at C-20 mph , since you 're moving in the same direction . But you do n't . Instead , you also measure it to be C. So how can this paradox be resolved ?

When you give a computer a command to do something random, it uses a special program called a "random number generator" to come up with a random answer. A random number generator is like a machine that can spit out any number at all, and it's really hard to predict what number it will spit out next. For example, if you tell a computer to play a song on shuffle, it might use a random number generator to decide which song to play first. It might choose a number between 1 and 100, and then it will look at a list of 100 songs and play the one that corresponds to the number it chose. Similarly, if you ask a computer to generate a random integer (a whole number like 1, 2, 3, etc.), it will use a random number generator to come up with a number. You can specify a range of numbers that you want the computer to choose from, like "pick a random number between 1 and 10," and the computer will use its random number generator to choose a number within that range. Finally, they attach the pier to the shore with cables or rods to keep it in place.A bridge is a structure that is built over a river, road, or other obstacle to allow people and vehicles to cross from one side to the other. In a game 's development it 's the director 's work to ensure that the work is divided across the teams and that they 're working constructively towards the director 's vision . The second point is that a significant amount of quality control and testing goes into any good piece of software ( and sometimes even bad software , but there 's only so much you can do ) . Large studios will have multiple teams of quality control covering testing from hardware compliance to bug - hunting . Nothing fits together perfectly on the first try , and sometimes bug fixes in one area cause problems in others - QA is a huge part of making any piece of software polished .

When you're in an airplane, you don't feel like you're tipping sideways because you and everything else inside the airplane are moving together as a unit. The plane is designed to stay level and balanced even when it's tilting or turning.Imagine that you're sitting in a chair on a big, flat surface. If you tilt the surface you're sitting on, you'll feel like you're tilting with it because you and the chair are moving together. But if you tilt your chair while you're sitting on a flat surface, you'll feel like you're tilting because the chair is moving, but the surface you're sitting on is staying still.It's the same thing with an airplane. When the plane tilts or turns, everything inside the plane moves together, so you don't feel like you're tilting or moving around. But when you're in a car, the car is moving and turning, but you and everything else inside the car are staying relatively still, so you feel like you're moving back and forth.

Heritable traits are characteristics or traits that are passed down from a parent to their offspring through their genes. These traits can be physical characteristics, such as eye color, hair color, and height, or they can be behavioral traits, such as intelligence, personality, and susceptibility to certain diseases.Heritable traits are determined by the genes that are passed from one generation to the next. Genes are made up of DNA, which contains the instructions for how our bodies develop and function. When a parent passes on their genes to their offspring, they pass on the instructions for the traits that they possess.Heritability is a measure of how much of the variation in a particular trait can be attributed to genetics. Some traits are more heritable than others, meaning that they are more influenced by genetics and less influenced by environmental factors. For example, traits such as eye color and height tend to be more heritable than traits such as intelligence and personality, which are influenced by both genetics and environment.It is important to note that heritability does not mean that a trait is fixed or unchangeable. While genetics play a role in determining an individual's traits, environmental factors also play a role in shaping an individual's characteristics.

Gavrilo Princip, a member of the Young Bosnia movement, assassinated Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria-Hungary in Sarajevo on June 28, 1914. This event was one of the key triggers for World War I, as the assassination set off a chain of events that ultimately led to the declaration of war by the major powers of Europe. Ferdinand was the heir to the Austro-Hungarian throne, and his assassination was seen as a direct threat to the stability of the Austro-Hungarian Empire. As a result, Austria-Hungary declared war on Serbia, and the other major powers of Europe, including Germany, France, and Russia, became involved in the conflict.

Cell phones do have caller ID, just like landlines. When someone calls you on your cell phone, their phone number should appear on the screen. If you have their number saved in your phone's contact list, their name should also appear.There are a few reasons why landlines and cell phones might handle caller ID differently. One reason is that landlines are often connected to a specific location, like a house or an office. This means that the phone company knows exactly who is calling and can display their name and number on the caller ID.Cell phones, on the other hand, are portable and can be used anywhere. This means that the phone company might not always have access to information about who is calling, so they can only show the phone number.Another reason is that cell phones have limited space on the screen to display information. Landlines usually have a larger screen or a separate display for caller ID, so they can show more information. Cell phones, on the other hand, have smaller screens and might not have as much room to display both the name and the number of the caller.Overall, both landlines and cell phones have caller ID, but they might display the information differently because of the differences in how they work and the limited space on cell phone screens.

Yes.  The investment world is extremely fast-paced and competitive. There are loads of professional traders with supercomputers working day in and day out to make smarter, faster trade decisions than you. If you try to compete with them, there’s a better than fair chance you’ll lose precious time and money, which kind of defeats the purpose. A good wealth manager: In short, they can save you time and money and help you take the most advantage of your current savings. Or, you can think about it in terms of cost. Most wealth managers charge an annual fee (as a % of the amount invested) for their services. This fee can range anywhere from close to zero, to 0.75% depending upon how sophisticated the strategy is that the money will be invested in, and what kind of additional services they have to offer. Investing in the S&P500 on the behalf of the investor shouldn’t need a fee, but investing in a smart beta or an alpha strategy, that generates returns independent of the market’s movement and certainly commands a fee. But how does one figure if that fee is justified? It is really simple. What is the risk-adjusted performance of the strategy? What is the Sharpe ratio? Large successful funds like Renaissance Technologies and Citadel can charge 3% in addition to 30% of profits because even after that their returns are much better than the market. I am not a doctor . This is not medical advice , but I have lived with three different people prone to panic attacks and learned this that way : * * What happens during a panic attack * * ( Please note : there may be other things at play : this is the " what happens " that I know about , and I believe is most common , as I know several people who suffered from these . ) A panic attack is triggered by something - often specific to the person suffering , or sometimes they just happen on their own . The panic response ( in everyone ) triggers heavy breathing to get as much oxygen into the blood as possible ready for

a fight - or - flight response . However , in a panic attack this heavy breathing ( hyperventilating ) is overdone , and it actually makes it harder to breath . The sensation of not being able to breath causes new waves of panic , and so it continues . * * What you can do * * Firstly , do not panic yourself . The first time I saw someone have a panic attack I thought she was choking on someone , and started trying to hit her on the back . That was n't so helpful , as it turned out . You should be the paragon of calm . A panic attack is not dangerous . If someone really overdoes the hyperventilating they will

trigger a " breathing reset " sort of thing , which sorts out their breathing and they quickly calm down . Even if this does n't happen ( which I 've never known to happen ) the worst that can happen is that they 'll fall asleep , but anyway . Secondly , be comforting . One person I knew who was prone to them had flashbacks to a traumatic event that triggered her . By hugging her closely , and talking to her I 'd override her flashback - senses with real - world - here - and - now senses and bring her out of the flashback and she 'd calm down quickly . To her I said things like " You 're okay , you

of my grip ( tighter , gentler , etc ... ) to try to subtly adjust her breathing and found that worked . Thirdly , talk to them . Some people do n't like talking about it , but you can talk about how to help them . This means you find out what makes certain people want to punch you , or useful things like the " bring them out of flashbacks " and stuff .

Hiccups are caused by a sudden, involuntary contraction of the diaphragm, the muscle that separates the chest from the abdomen and helps you breathe. When the diaphragm contracts suddenly, it causes a person to inhale quickly, which can make the vocal cords snap shut and produce the "hic" sound that is characteristic of hiccups. There are many things that can cause the diaphragm to contract suddenly and cause hiccups, such as eating too quickly, drinking carbonated beverages, or having a full stomach. Hiccups can also be caused by certain medications, infections, or medical conditions such as acid reflux. In most cases, hiccups are not a serious problem and will go away on their own after a short period of time. However, if hiccups last for a long time or are causing discomfort, there are a few things that you can try to help stop them, such as holding your breath, swallowing sugar, or drinking a glass of water upside down.

There are several ways they figure out how a fire was started from when they first arrive on the scene to when the fire is completely extinguished . It is commonly believed that a fire destroys all evidence of it 's source , but actually , the fire department usually gets there in time to stop it before it incinerates everything . Firefighters note the color of the flame , color of the smoke , amount of the smoke , how fast it burns , and even the sound the fire makes while it is burning . ( Burning wood sounds different when it 's been soaked with kerosene , for example ) . The fire inspector , investigators , or whoever it is that inspects the scene

( varies by state and city ) looks for things like [ char pattern ] ( URL_1 ) . Fire burns in a V - shape , so sometimes the char pattern can literally point to the origin ( like an outlet ) . Narrower V - shapes say that the fire was hotter than normal so something like gasoline or kerosene was used . A U - shape says that there was a " pool " of origin rather than a point of origin . Other things like the direction something melts can also help figure out how the fire was started . Light bulbs tend to melt towards the point of origin . Once the origin had been found , usually the next step is to

determine if the fire was natural , electrical or chemical . Natural causes are usually pretty easy to determine . There is plenty of evidence , and usually witnesses , when a house is struck by lightning or enveloped by a California brush fire , for instance . Electrical problems are the most common cause of accidental fires . By examining a cord , or a fuse box , or an electric outlet , an expert can usually determine whether it was burned * by * the fire , or was the * source * of the fire . Chemical causes cover a wide range , from gas leak explosions to smoking in bed . They also look for unburnt clues . The shattered or cracked glass of

imply a very hot fire , possibly due to an accelerant . The depth or thickness of the ash can be indicative . For example , a thick layer of ash can mean an abnormally hot , fast - burning fire . Fire burns upward , so a fire that burned downward will arouse curiosity . The most common reason for a fire to burn downward is the presence of a liquid accelerant poured on the floor before the fire started . The liquid soaked down into the floor , and then the fire followed it downward to the concrete slab . [ Source of all this information . ] ( URL_0 )

Automatic speech recognition (ASR) is a technology that enables computers to recognize and transcribe spoken language into written or computer-readable text. ASR systems can be used to transcribe spoken words into text for a variety of applications, such as dictation, transcription of recorded speech, or real-time captioning of live events.ASR systems use complex algorithms and machine learning techniques to analyze spoken language and identify the words and phrases being spoken. The system compares the spoken input to a database of pre-recorded words and phrases and uses statistical models to determine the most likely transcription.ASR systems have become increasingly accurate and widespread in recent years, and are used in a variety of applications including voice assistants, transcription services, and speech-to-text software. They have the potential to significantly improve productivity and accessibility for individuals who have difficulty typing or writing, and can also be used to transcribe spoken language in multiple languages.

Gravity is a force that attracts two objects with mass towards each other. We can't see or touch gravity, but we can observe its effects. For example, if you drop a ball, it will fall towards the ground because the Earth's gravity is pulling it down. The speed at which gravity travels is called the "speed of gravity" or the "gravitational propagation speed."Scientists have conducted many experiments to try to measure the speed of gravity. However, it is very difficult to measure because it is so weak compared to other forces, like electricity and magnetism. Even though we can't measure the exact speed of gravity, we do know that it must travel at or near the speed of light because that is the fastest speed that anything can travel.Does that make sense? It 's actually our brains that react to optical illusions . The light that enters our eyes is converted into neuronal impulses ( an electric and chemical message ) and sent to the back of our brains , an area called the Occipital Cortex . That area of the brain organizes the information our eyes report to make sense . There are bits of our brain that look for certain lines and angles , contrast , and shapes . Those areas then report to other areas of increasing complexity . We have evolved to sense depth and motion based on certain cues , like shading -- this results in a whole bunch of optical illusions , where our brain misinterprets the information that the eyes report .

Let me offer an anecdote to this -  I started helping a woman, widowed, retired, who had been paying $500/yr to get her taxes done. As I mentioned in my comment here, she got a checklist each year and provided the info requested. From where I sat, it seemed a clerk entered the info into tax software.  As part of the transition to me helping her, I asked the prior guy (very nice guy, really) for a quick consult. She took the standard deduction, but also showed a nice annual donation. Didn't take advantage of the QCD, donate directly from an IRA (she was over 70-1/2) to save on the tax of this sum. That could have saved her $500.  She was in the 15% bracket, with some room left for a Roth conversion. Converting just enough to 'fill' that bracket each year seemed a decent strategy as it would avoid the 25% rate as her RMDs rose each year and would push her to 25%. To both items the guy suggested that this was not his area, he was not a financial planner. Yes, I understand different expertise. With how simple her return was, I didn't understand the value he added.  If you go with a professional, be sure you have an understanding of what he will and won't do for you.

Memorizing a grocery list is hard when the items have nothing to do with each other . But it 's easier if they do . If you 're a baker , and you need to go get flour , sugar , butter , and eggs , it 's pretty easy to remember that list because they 're the 4 basic baking ingredients . But if the list is 3 yellow onions , a quart of half - and - half , toothpaste , and dog food , it 's going to be really easy to forget something . That 's the key to memorization . Your brain can really only hold on to so many things at once ( I 've heard 7 as an upper limit )

Hubert Lederer Dreyfus (/ˈdraɪfəs/; October 15, 1929 – April 22, 2017) was an American philosopher and professor of philosophy at the University of California, Berkeley. His main interests included phenomenology, existentialism and the philosophy of both psychology and literature, as well as the philosophical implications of artificial intelligence. He was widely known for his exegesis of Martin Heidegger, which critics labeled "Dreydegger".Dreyfus was featured in Tao Ruspoli's film Being in the World (2010), and was among the philosophers interviewed by Bryan Magee for the BBC Television series The Great Philosophers (1987).The Futurama character Professor Hubert Farnsworth is partly named after him, writer Eric Kaplan having been a former student.

Yes, it is possible to avoid fees when trading Contracts for Difference (CFDs). Many CFD brokers offer commission-free trading, which means that you won't be charged a separate fee for each trade you make. Instead, the broker will build the cost of the trade into the spread, which is the difference between the buy and sell price of the underlying asset.There are also ways to minimize fees when trading CFDs even if you are using a broker that charges commissions. One strategy is to trade infrequently, as each trade will incur a commission. You can also look for brokers that offer volume discounts, which can reduce the overall cost of trading for active traders.It's important to note that while it is possible to minimize or avoid fees when trading CFDs, there are still other costs to consider, such as financing costs for overnight positions and the potential for losses on your trades. It's always a good idea to carefully review the fees and charges associated with any financial product before you start trading.

Alpha - beta pruning is an optimization to tree search . Details of how it improves tree search are fairly boring IMO , basically it 's one of those things that you assume are bolted onto any tree search unless otherwise stated . So what is tree search ? Trees are basically graphs . Composed of two things , nodes and connections between the nodes . One node is a root , and then some other nodes are connected to the root . Then some more are connected to single parent node on the layer above . Tree search then means looking for some specific kind of node from a structure like this . Like , you can see chess positions as trees . If from opening ,

white moves queen pawn two forward , that 's one node that 's connected to the root , the opening position . But you have other children nodes as well . Like , white could 've moved a knight as well . And for each of these moves , there 's a response , which creates a new node , and so on . Chess engines build trees like this , and try to assign each node with a score , " how good is this position for white ? " . Tree search part is then about finding the best next move given all the scores for moves . Alpha - beta pruning specifically helps massively reduce the number of nodes computer has to shuffle through .

Humans are pattern - seeking primates that can reach conclusions before all the parts are aligned . This became hard - wired due to its evolutionary - adaptiveness and survival value . For example : hearing the grass rustle because a predator is lurking nearby . Sometimes the premonition turns out to be false but it is still better than dying from the genetic point of view . Also , the subconscious mind is always a few seconds ahead of consciousness . The " gut feeling " phenomenon of intuition exists because the gut has its own nervous system that can act independently and sends messages to the brain before it becomes aware of the environmental cue .

Sure! Imagine you're standing outside on a clear night and you look up at the sky. You see lots of stars, right? But you also see lots of darkness between the stars. That's because most of the universe is empty space, and there aren't many stars or other objects in it to give off light.Now, let's think about why we can see the stars at all. When you look at a star, what you're really seeing is the light that the star is giving off. Light travels through the empty space between stars and reaches your eyes, so you can see the stars. But if there aren't many stars or other objects around to give off light, then there won't be much light to see, and the space will look dark.So, the reason space is so dark is because most of it is empty, and there aren't many stars or other objects to give off light. But even though it's dark, we can still see the stars because their light travels through the empty space and reaches our eyes.

The "Rime of the Ancient Mariner" is a long poem by the English poet Samuel Taylor Coleridge, published in 1798. It tells the story of a sailor who is punished for shooting an albatross, a large sea bird, and must endure a long and difficult journey as a result. The poem is known for its vivid and imaginative language, as well as its themes of guilt, redemption, and the natural world. Coleridge wrote the poem while he was living in Germany, and it was published in a collection of poems called "Lyrical Ballads" that he co-authored with William Wordsworth.

According to the Bible, Ezekiel was a priest and was among the Jews who were exiled to Babylon after the fall of Jerusalem.In the book of Ezekiel, the prophet delivers messages from God to the exiled Jews, warning them of the consequences of their sins and calling on them to repent. He also delivers prophecies about the future restoration of Israel and the coming of a savior.Ezekiel's prophecies and messages are known for their vivid and often bizarre imagery, which has made his book a source of fascination for readers of the Bible for centuries.

distinct meanings) are concepts used in linguistics, specifically in the study of syntax in the Chomskyan tradition of transformational generative grammar.The deep structure of a linguistic expression is a theoretical construct that seeks to unify several related structures.  For example, the sentences "Pat loves Chris" and "Chris is loved by Pat" mean roughly the same thing and use similar words.  Some linguists, Chomsky in particular, have tried to account for this similarity by positing that these two sentences are distinct surface forms that derive from a common (or very similar) deep structure.

Cognitive science is the interdisciplinary, scientific study of the mind and its processes with input from linguistics, psychology, neuroscience, philosophy, computer science/artificial intelligence, and anthropology. It examines the nature, the tasks, and the functions of cognition (in a broad sense). Cognitive scientists study intelligence and behavior, with a focus on how nervous systems represent, process, and transform information. Mental faculties of concern to cognitive scientists include language, perception, memory, attention, reasoning, and emotion; to understand these faculties, cognitive scientists borrow from fields such as linguistics, psychology, artificial intelligence, philosophy, neuroscience, and anthropology. The typical analysis of cognitive science spans many levels of organization, from learning and decision to logic and planning; from neural circuitry to modular brain organization. One of the fundamental concepts of cognitive science is that "thinking can best be understood in terms of representational structures in the mind and computational procedures that operate on those structures."The goal of cognitive science is to understand and formulate the principles of intelligence with the hope that this will lead to a better comprehension of the mind and of learning.The cognitive sciences began as an intellectual movement in the 1950s often referred to as the cognitive revolution.

There are a few reasons why websites might display the age of a post rather than the actual date it was posted. One reason is that it can make the content feel more relevant to the reader. If a post was made a few days ago, it might not seem as important or timely as a post made just a few hours ago. Displaying the age of the post in years or months can give the reader a better sense of how long ago it was made, and can make the content feel more current. Another reason why websites might display the age of a post rather than the actual date is to save space. Displaying the date a post was made can take up a lot of room on the screen, especially if the date is long and includes the month, day, and year. By displaying the age of the post instead, websites can save space and make it easier for readers to quickly scan and find the information they are looking for. Finally, displaying the age of a post rather than the actual date can also make it easier for readers to compare the age of different posts. If all of the posts on a website are displayed with their age rather than their actual date, it can be easier for readers to see which posts are newer and which are older at a glance.

The Big Bang is the idea that the universe began as a very small, hot, and dense point, which then expanded and cooled over billions of years to form the universe we see today. Scientists believe that this expansion began about 13.8 billion years ago, and that the universe is still expanding today.It's hard to explain exactly how the Big Bang happened, because it happened so long ago and we don't have any direct evidence of what happened. However, scientists have developed theories about the early universe based on observations of the universe today and the laws of physics.One way to think about it is to imagine the universe as a balloon. When the balloon is small and not blown up, it represents the early universe, which was very small and dense. As you blow up the balloon, it expands and becomes bigger, just like the universe has expanded over time.It's important to note that the Big Bang is just a theory, and scientists are still trying to learn more about the early universe and how it has evolved over time.

In addition to the excellent answers here I might suggest a reason for investing in leveraged funds and the original purpose for their existence.  Lets say you run a mutual fund that is supposed to track the performance of the S&P 500.   If you have cash inflows and outflows from your fund due to people investing and selling shares of your fund you may have periods where not all funds are invested appropriately because some of the funds are in cash.  Lets say 98% of your funds are invested in the securities that reflect the stocks in the S&P 500.  You will will miss matching the S&P 500 because you have 2% not invested in some money market account.   If you take 1/3 of the cash balance and invest in a triple leveraged fund or take 1/2 of the funds and invest in a double leveraged fund you will more accurately track the index to which your fund is supposed to track.  I am not sure what percentage mutual fund owners keep in cash but this is one use that I know these ETFs are used for. The shape of a price history graph is governed by the forces of supply and demand in the market for a particular asset or product. When the demand for an asset or product is greater than the supply, the price will tend to rise, and the price history graph will show an upward trend. Conversely, when the supply of an asset or product is greater than the demand, the price will tend to fall, and the price history graph will show a downward trend.There are many factors that can influence supply and demand in a market, including economic conditions, political events, technological developments, and market sentiment. For example, if there is a recession, demand for certain products or assets may decrease, causing the price to fall. On the other hand, if there is a technological innovation that makes a product more efficient or desirable, demand for that product may increase, leading to an increase in price.It is also important to note that the shape of a price history graph can be affected by other factors, such as the availability of information about the asset or product and the level of liquidity in the market. Finally, it is worth noting that price history graphs are not always smooth and continuous, and may show significant fluctuations or changes in trend over time.

The urge to pee is related to the pressure inside the bladder , which is in turn related to the amount of urine being stored there . But this is not direct because there are other factors at play such as the body 's response to bladder filling . A cystometrogram ( ' cysto- ' meaning bladder , ' metro- ' meaning measure and ' -gram ' meaning write ) is a graph that measures the pressure inside the bladder relative to the amount of fluid in the bladder . See [ here ] ( URL_0 ) for an example from a well known physiology textbook . When there is no urine in the bladder , the pressure is zero . By the time 30 – 50 mL

have collected in the bladder , the pressure rises a little , and this is called phase Ia. 200 – 300 mL of urine may collect with only a small increase in the pressure inside the bladder . This constancy of pressure is caused by the tone of the bladder wall itself , which relaxes and gets larger as it fills . This brings in a physical principle known as the Law of Laplace . Basically this law says that the pressure in a spherical vessel ( like your bladder ) is twice the wall tension divided by the radius . If you increase the radius by making the vessel larger , the pressure will decrease . This phase of filling is known as Ib . Even though

to urinate ( like fear ) , and as thermiter36 said , pressure from other organs ( mainly a problem for pregnant women , or women with uterine masses etc . ) may stimulate the need to urinate . TL : DR - the urge to urinate is proportional to the pressure in the bladder , which is not only related to the amount of pee stored there , but also the body 's response to bladder filling and other factors .

Firewire is a type of computer interface used to connect devices such as digital cameras, digital video cameras, and external hard drives to a computer. It is a high-speed serial bus that allows for the transfer of data at high speeds, typically up to 400 megabits per second. Firewire was originally developed by Apple, but it has also been adopted by other manufacturers. It is often used to connect devices that require fast data transfer speeds, such as video editing equipment and large external hard drives. Firewire is also sometimes used to connect devices that require a stable, low-latency connection, such as audio recording equipment.

This information should be available on your brokerage statement or through your brokerage account.Next, you will need to determine the price you paid for each share of JCI stock. This information should also be available on your brokerage statement or through your brokerage account.Once you have this information, you can calculate your cost basis in the JCI stock by multiplying the number of shares you owned by the price you paid for each share. This will give you the total amount you invested in the JCI stock.To calculate the tax consequences of the merger, you will need to consider the type of merger that occurred. If the merger was a taxable event, you will need to report any gain or loss on your tax return. If the merger was a tax-free event, you will not have any tax consequences to report.It is important to note that the cost basis and tax consequences of a merger can be complex and may vary depending on your specific circumstances. It is always a good idea to consult with a tax professional for guidance on how to report the merger on your tax return.

General Joseph Warren, a Continental Army officer, was killed at the Battle of Bunker Hill on June 17, 1775. He was shot in the head while leading the charge against the British during the battle. The Battle of Bunker Hill was a significant early engagement in the American Revolutionary War and took place on Breed's Hill, just outside of Boston, Massachusetts. The battle was a major victory for the British, but it was also a turning point in the war as it demonstrated that the colonists were capable of putting up a strong resistance against the British army.

Every song is in a certain key . The key of a song can be worked out by knowing the notes of the song , but good musicians can tell what key a song is in just by listening . Basically , the key of a song is a label , like " A " , " B " or " C " that musicians give to a song so they know how to play things over the top of it that sound good . Once a musican knows the key of a song , he or she might want to play something , like a guitar solo , or a violin melody , over the top of it . A scale is just a list of notes

that sound good over a piece of music . So if you know the key of a song , you pick a scale , and play only notes in that scale . Scales are how musicians " improvise " over music - they are basically safe notes that will always sound quite good . But to play really well of course requires more than just knowing scales - you need a lot of practise and a good musical ear . Different scales have different feels - some have a happy sound , like the major scale , and some have a sad sound , like the minor scale . Which scale you pick depends on how you want the tune to sound . Modes are really just special

are seven modes , each of which has a different " feel " to it . The most simple mode is called the Ionian , which is the major scale ( the happy scale we talked about ) . Then for example the Phrygian mode sounds very spanish ( think of the Miserlou opening to Pulp Fiction , if you ever managed to watch it when your parents were out ) . Some of the modes sound very strange and are only used by crazy musicians with weird hair and silly shoes . So the key is the label , the scale are the good notes that you can play if you know the key , and modes are really just special types of scales .

Nitrous oxide, also known as "NOS" or "laughing gas," is a chemical compound that is often used to boost the performance of race cars. When it is injected into the engine of a car, it can provide a temporary increase in horsepower and torque, which can make the car go faster.Nitrous oxide works by increasing the amount of oxygen that is available to the engine. When an engine burns fuel, it needs oxygen to help it burn. The more oxygen that is available, the more fuel the engine can burn, and the more power it can produce. Nitrous oxide is a gas that contains a lot of oxygen, so when it is injected into the engine, it provides a boost of oxygen that can help the engine burn more fuel and produce more power.However, it's important to note that nitrous oxide is not a substitute for regular gasoline. It is simply a temporary boost that can be used to help a car go faster in short bursts. It is not meant to be used all the time, and it can be dangerous if it is not used properly. In the Fast and Furious movies, the characters often use nitrous oxide to make their cars go faster in illegal street races, which is not a safe or legal activity in real life.

It is not uncommon for individuals who have had total knee replacement surgery to experience some pain or discomfort in the operated knee, particularly in the first few weeks or months after surgery. However, if you have been experiencing pain in the operated knee for the past 3 weeks and it is not getting better, it is important to speak with your orthopedic surgeon or primary care doctor for further evaluation and treatment.There are a few different treatment options that may be recommended to help manage pain in the operated knee, depending on the underlying cause of the pain. These may include:Pain medication: Over-the-counter or prescription pain medication can help reduce pain and inflammation in the knee.Physical therapy: A physical therapist can work with you to develop a plan to help improve range of motion, strength, and mobility in the knee.Ice and heat therapy: Applying ice to the affected area can help reduce swelling and inflammation, while heat therapy can help increase blood flow and relax muscles.Assistive devices: Using a cane or knee brace can help take some of the weight off the knee and provide additional support.It is important to speak with your doctor or physical therapist to determine the best treatment options for your specific situation. They may also recommend additional tests, such as X-rays or MRI, to determine the cause of your knee pain and guide treatment.

No, two consenting minors having sex would not be considered rape. In order for an act to be considered rape, it must involve non-consensual sexual activity. This means that one or more of the individuals involved did not give their freely given and enthusiastic consent to the sexual activity. Consent is an important part of any sexual activity, and it is important for all individuals involved to make sure that everyone is comfortable and willing before engaging in any sexual activity. If anyone is not fully on board or if there is any doubt about whether or not all parties have given their full and enthusiastic consent, it is important to stop and talk about it before continuing. So, to summarize, rape is when someone is forced to have sex or participate in sexual activity against their will. If both people involved in a sexual encounter are willing and enthusiastic participants, it is not rape.

Eraserhead is a surrealist film that was released in 1977. It was directed by David Lynch and follows the story of a man named Henry who lives in a bleak, industrial city. Henry has a baby with his girlfriend, but the baby is deformed and cries constantly, causing Henry a lot of stress and anxiety. The movie includes a number of strange and surreal elements, such as a lady who lives in Henry's radiator and sings to him, and a group of people who appear to be in some kind of alternate dimension. Overall, the movie is meant to be interpreted in a symbolic or allegorical way, rather than as a literal story. It explores themes of isolation, parenthood, and the meaning of life, among other things. Some people have interpreted the movie as being about the fear and confusion that can come with becoming a parent for the first time, while others have seen it as a commentary on the bleak and oppressive nature of modern urban life. Ultimately, the meaning of the movie is open to interpretation and will depend on the viewer's own experiences and perspective.

All sorts of reasons . Translating anything is tricky since words and phrases often times do n't have direct equivalents in other language . Even when they do , there are philosophical disagreements between translators on how a text should be presented . Take the phrase " 40 days and 40 nights . " In ancient Hebrew , that phrase is an expression that means a very long time . But it does n't mean that in English . So should you present the literal translation or the understood translation ? Translators ca n't agree . The understood translation seems better , but that can fall into the trap of presenting a biased version . A good example is the Jehovah 's Witness bible that was translated in

that 's the way most people think of the bible . Ask anyone to name one of the Ten Commandments and they 'll probably say something that starts with " thou shalt not . " Or the phrase " easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle ... " That 's actually a mistranslation . The word camel should be rope , but it 's such a famous line that many new translations keep it in . Translating anything is tough and all these problems are compounded when you are asked to translate what millions consider to be the word of God .

Sure! Imagine that you have a big bucket of water and you want to pour it into a smaller cup that is far away from the bucket. You could use a hose to try to transfer the water from the bucket to the cup. This is similar to how we use pipelines to move oil and other liquids over long distances. However, water is heavy and it is hard to pump it through a hose over long distances. This is why it is difficult to build pipelines to move water across the country. On the other hand, oil is a lot lighter than water, so it is easier to pump it through a pipeline. Oil pipelines can be built underground, which helps to protect them from the weather and makes them safer. Water pipelines would also have to be built underground to protect them, but this would be more expensive and more difficult to do. In addition to the technical challenges, there are also many other factors to consider when building pipelines, such as the cost of construction, the impact on the environment, and the rights of the people who live near the pipeline. All of these factors make it difficult to build pipelines to move water across the country, even though it might seem like a good idea at first.

Prohibition was put into place by the 18th Amendment to the United States Constitution. This amendment made it illegal to make, sell, or transport alcohol throughout the country. However, Prohibition did not work very well. Many people continued to drink alcohol, and some even made it themselves or bought it from people who were selling it illegally. This led to a rise in crime, as people who wanted to make and sell alcohol often had to break the law in order to do so. Ultimately, Prohibition was repealed by the 21st Amendment to the United States Constitution, which made it legal to make, sell, and transport alcohol again.

Not including the compound of the rubber ( race ties being softer , and usually of a different chemical makeup ) , the difference comes down to water and heat cycles . Race tires without treads make the most contact , but they are used only in the dry . Consumer tires have to handle multiple conditions , including water . The treads channel water away from the tires surface , allowing the tire to make contact with the road instead of floating on top of the water . Consumer tires have far less traction when " bald " usually due to heat cycling , and the fact the the compound at that level is often different than the compound at the surface when a tire is newer . Heat cycling is essentially the hardening of the rubber each time the tire warms up and cools down . The harder the tire , the less grip . Many racers that are restricted to " street " tires will often shave tread off of brand new tires to reduce the amount of tread " squirm " and often get to a different compound ( if the tire is molded in such a way ) .

Fire insurance, as you have discovered, is a complete ripoff. The ISS along with all its cargo and astronauts is in an orbit , which in GR is just straight - line movement . You can not push something off course except with an external force . It would be like trying to push yourself while sitting in a cart . What happens is that on such a push , the astronauts goes flying backwards , and the ISS moves proportionally in the direction of the push ( conservation of momentum ) , but the astronaut inevitably inputs the same momentum transfer on the other side of the wall somewhere . If there was an open hatch and an astronaut were to push himself on the wall and then fly through the hatch , the ISS would actually gain some momentum in that direction ( and the astronaut would probably die ) . But you can not push the ISS out of orbit this way , because an orbit is a rather stable system , like a ball in a bowl , and you have to push the ISS strongly enough in the right direction to break it out of orbit , otherwise its orbital eccentricity changes slightly but it wo n't " fall to the Earth slowly " .

It 's a long story but here 's a simple summary : In Los Angeles , California there 's an area called South Central LA . Long ago the predominately black youth in this area were bored so they tried to venture out and join some local youth clubs . Because they were black they were n't allowed to join and because they were from South Central they were n't allowed to leave the area with out being harassed , beaten and arrested . So they started their own clubs in their own neighborhood . This did n't work out so well , because lacking any structure or adult supervision they got into trouble . Nothing too bad , maybe some vandalism or petty crime , but the

authorities came down fairly hard on them and pushed them toward more serious criminality due to a disparity in consequences . They often referred to each other as blood , the same way one might say bro , dude or buddy . These groups named themselves in the tradition of New York youth gangs . " The Dragons " , " Devils " or whatever might make adults nervous . A lot of years later some kids following in their predecessors footsteps and besieged by the same problems stole an elderly Korean woman 's groceries . Unable to clearly describe her assailants she seemed to be saying they were " crips " because as fate would have it one was using crutches or a cane and this was

as close to " cripples " as she could get . The media , in a recent frenzy over racial tension and violence in Beverley Hills , picked up on the story and ran it as long as they could , and this new gang they had discovered , the Crips , was born . Some kids felt left out because they were from a different part of South Central and no one seemed to care about their gangs , so they started calling themselves Bloods to get in on the hype . Eventually both the Blood and Crip monikers became associated with Red ( Bloods ) and Blue ( Crips ) colors and a long lasting rivalry had their banners . A few more years later the

two had become household names , violence brands , that began to be adopted all over the country then world . Different youth gangs that wanted more legitimacy folded into either group , largely arbitrarily or based on whom they ran into and what side they already claimed . Crips and Bloods both went out into the wilderness to recruit and forge new markets , and so their banners spread until every black youth gang west of the Mississippi were waving one or the other . Generally speaking there were a few differences between Crips and Bloods . The Crips were larger , though really there was never a good accounting of either 's ranks , but both agreed the Crips were the larger of the two .

The Bloods always said they were closer though , so this became part of the brand . Then Crack happened , a lot of money happened and things got worse and worse until around the South Central riots which started in poor Latino neighborhoods over a similar situation as with Rodney King but was universally ignored by the media . This spread to poor Black neighborhoods and the media so decreed it was a black race riot . The Latino 's were denied their spot light once again , but not for long . Immediately following the riots there was a calm , and then politics happened . Funny how it works , but a gang kills someone and they call the police , they plant a garden

a narrow passage that most criminals must one day navigate . And finally , after being denied their place in the annuals of criminal history the Latino gangs , or maybe more specificly the Mexican gangs , had arrived . No one seemed to care much anymore about those Red and Blue handkerchiefs . So now the Crip and Blood brands are diluted and the much more contemporary Mexican Mafia has became the height of crime fashion .

The term " alive " is arbitrary . If you chose a suitable definition of what is alive or not , viruses can be considered alive . They are not currently thought of in this way because we just have a standard definition . It 's somewhat controversial , but it does n't matter anyway : being " alive " does n't give you any special powers or unique features . It 's just a meaningless classification . It 's kind of like the age of " adulthood . " Nothing magical happens when you are above the determined age . It 's just an arbitrary number that we agree upon for convenience . We say " life has features A , B , and C. " What about feature D ? We just did n't include it . There 's no important reason ; we just had to stop somewhere , and we stopped at C because it does n't often conflict with how we used the word historically .

In your day to day life you deal with some things that are ~~quantified~~ quantized and some things that are continuous . For example , you could have 12 marbles , but you ca n't really have 12.5 marbles -- you would just have 12 marbles and some broken glass . By contrast , you can have 1 cup of water , or 1.5 cups , or 1 and 3/4 liters , or what have you -- any of these things is reasonable . When we ( as a species ) started to uncover the nature of matter and came across electrons they were first found as discrete , individual balls of charge with a little mass . We found that you can have 1 electron or 2

electrons , but you ca n't have 1.5 electrons -- it just does n't make sense to talk about fractions of electrons ; they do n't exist . In this sense we started to imagine electrons as little bitty particles . This is emphasized in popular descriptions of the atom , often based on the Bohr Model -- it 's the model that looks like a planet ( nucleus ) with moons ( electrons ) orbiting it . That model works quite nicely and makes lots of accurate predictions about the behavior of atoms , especially with respect to chemistry . However , as we looked deeper we realized that electrons behave like a wave . An example of this is the famous double slit experiment -- if

you send a wave towards a wall with two small holes in it then you get a certain interference pattern . [ Here ] ( URL_1 ) is a video from MIT that shows the pattern that you get from this experiment using water , which we know to allow waves ( it starts with single slits and moves to double slit interference later in the video ) . When we fired a stream of electrons at a pair of slits we got an odd result . Rather than the expected lack of interference that particles experience ( imagine throwing a tennis ball through a hole in the fence -- its path is unaltered ) , the electrons actually deflected and gave an interference pattern that suggests that

they are actually traveling as a * wave * . The experiment showed that the electrons were interfering with each other . As if that were n't brain - exploding enough , they then repeated the experiment shooting only one electron at a time and came up with the same pattern -- the electron travels through * both * slits , interferes with itself , then finally impacts the surface on which the interference pattern is being observed . For a particle such a description is ludicrous , but for a wave the description is expected . Returning to the structure of the atom , I mentioned the Bohr model earlier but that model is ultimately inaccurate . A more correct model is the electron cloud model --

In general, yes. If interest rates go higher, then any existing fixed-rate bonds - and hence ETFs holding those bonds - become less valuable. The further each bond is from maturity, the larger the impact. As you suggest, once the bonds do mature, the fund can replace them at a market price, so the effect tails off. The bond market has a concept known as "duration" that helps reason about this effect. Roughly, it measures the average time from now to each payout of the bond, weighted by the payout. The longer the duration, the more the price will change for a given change in interest rates. The concept is just an approximation, and there are various slightly different ways of calculating it; but very roughly the price of a bond will reduce by a percentage equal to the duration times the increase in interest rates. So a bond with a duration of 5 years will lose 5% of its value for a 1% rise in interest rates (and of course vice-versa). For your second question, it really depends on what you're trying to achieve by diversifying - this might be best as a different question that gives more detail, as it's not very related to your first question. Short-term bonds are less risky. But both will lose value if the underlying company is in trouble. Gilts (government bonds) are less risky than corporate bonds.

Yes, fire does have mass. Mass is a measure of the amount of matter in an object. Fire is made up of a mixture of gases, including oxygen, and small particles such as soot and ash. These substances all have mass and contribute to the overall mass of the fire.To understand why fire has mass, it's helpful to think about what happens when something burns. When a substance burns, it reacts with oxygen in the air to create heat, light, and a new set of substances. The substances produced by the burning process, such as soot and ash, are what we see as the fire. These substances have mass, just like any other matter.So, to sum it up, fire does have mass because it is made up of matter that has mass.

Your only option at that point is to attack the whole thing and hope you can kill it all . It 's not a perfect analogy , obviously , and even those that get there quick enough to have the tumor simply be removed will possibly need chemo / radiation to kill cells around the effected area , but it helped me to understand how if you have colon cancer that has spread to the liver , or lungs , or both , that just ' removing the cancer ' is near impossible .

Essentially , communism in an intended end - stage of revolution that includes the abolition of currency , class , and governmental control of the means of production . There is a common misconception that the USSR was end - stage communist . It never was - anyone that has actually read Marx will tell you that the system instated by the Soviets was not in any shape or fashion the intended goal of the revolution . Communism is not inherently bad . The basic idea can be summed up as " from each their ability , to each their need " - but NOT as mandated by a state . Western educations ( especially in the US ) have tended to confuse the desirable theoretical end -

to help the community ) with the statist mid - stage that has pervaded every single " communist " state in history . Realistically , communism should be seen as bad because attempts to achieve it usually end with millions of people dying , rather than the idea itself being bad . A flip side of the coin is anarchism , a form of social organisation that promotes the idea of a transition into what essentially amounts to a communist utopia WITHOUT the transitory government stage that apparently messes everything up . Whether or not you think that 's realistic is up to you , I guess .

Great question! A, E, I, O, and U are considered vowels because they are the most common sounds that we make with our voices when we want to say a word. They are different from consonants because consonants are made when we use our mouth and voice to block the flow of air as we say them. For example, when we say the consonant "b," we use our lips to block the flow of air. But when we say the vowel "a," we don't block the flow of air at all - we just let it flow freely through our mouths. Does that help?

Hard drives are devices that store digital data using spinning disks and magnetic fields. These disks are made of metal and are coated with a special material that can be magnetized. When you save a file on a hard drive, the hard drive's computer (called a controller) breaks the file down into tiny pieces called bits. The controller then sends these bits to the spinning disks, where they are stored as patterns of magnetism. The patterns of magnetism represent the 1s and 0s of digital information. A 1 is represented by a north magnetic pole, while a 0 is represented by a south magnetic pole. By storing the 1s and 0s as magnetic patterns on the spinning disks, the hard drive can remember the data even when it's not connected to a power source. Hard drives are limited in the amount of data they can store because there is only so much room on the spinning disks. The more data you want to store, the more disks you need, and the bigger the hard drive has to be. I hope that helps to explain how hard drives work! Let me know if you have any other questions.

There seems to be a lot of confusion regarding terms like * sex , race , gender , orientation ... * SEX : Your biological sex is determined by chromosomes . Most people are born XY ( male ) or XX ( female ) but some people can be born Intersex where their chromosomes do not match up with their external ( testes / ovaries ) or internal ( penis / vagina ) sex characteristics . GENDER : Who you subjectively define yourself as . Typically either as " feminine " or " masculine " . What constitutes these two dichotomous classifications is largely influenced by culture . What is considered " feminine " in America , may not be be in India . A person may not

feel they have a gender identity or they may feel they are somewhere in between masculine and feminine . ORIENTATION : Who you like sexually . You may like men ( sex ) or women ( sex ) , or both or neither . You may like feminine ( gender ) individuals or masculine ( gender ) individuals or you may not have a preference . * * Gender is who you go into bed as . Orientation is who you want to go to bed with . * * Race : Is a socio - cultural classification system of people that is not relevant to biology . Biologists , scientists , anthropologists DO NOT use racial classifications because racial classifications involve shifting sets of paradigms . What

defined a " black " person in 1500 's Europe is not the same as " black " person living in America . " Social conceptions and groupings of races vary over time , involving folk taxonomies that define essential types of individuals based on perceived traits . Scientists consider biological essentialism obsolete , and generally discourage racial explanations for collective differentiation in both physical and behavioral traits . " Race is all but superficial , and we only need look at Apartheid legislation to understand that classifying people into different races does n't work . For example , in South Africa a brother and sister were classified one as " coloured " and the other as " white " because the one sibling failed the test of

being able to have a pencil fall out of their hair . Curly hair was considered a " coloured " characteristic . If you want to look at someones genes to determine their ancestry that is OK . But instead of looking at RACES you would be looking at a POPULATION . Populations are definable groups of people who are more likely to mate and reproduce with each other than members outside that population . In terms of gene flow , gene inheritance etc it makes more sense to look at the world as populations of humans . A population might be a small village in Africa or the whole continent of Asia depending on your question , its scope and the specific traits your interested in .

The border between two countries or states that is a river is called a "border river". When a border river changes course over time, the border between the two countries or states also changes. This is because the border is based on the location of the river. If the river moves, the border moves with it. This can sometimes cause problems, because the boundary between the two areas may not be clear, and it may be difficult to tell which country or state certain land or buildings belong to. However, there are usually agreements in place between the two countries or states to help deal with these kinds of changes, and to make sure that everyone knows where the border is.

Category theory is a general theory of mathematical structures and their relations that was introduced by Samuel Eilenberg and Saunders Mac Lane in the middle of the 20th century in their foundational work on algebraic topology. Nowadays, category theory is used in almost all areas of mathematics, and in some areas of computer science. In particular, many constructions of new mathematical objects from previous ones, that appear similarly in several contexts are conveniently expressed and unified in terms of categories. Examples include quotient spaces, direct products, completion, and duality.A category is formed by two sorts of objects: the objects of the category, and the morphisms, which relate two objects called the source and the target of the morphism. One often says that a morphism is an arrow that

the monoid.The second fundamental concept of category is the concept of a functor, which plays the role of a morphism between two categories C1{\displaystyle C_{1}} and C2:{\displaystyle C_{2}:} it maps objects of C1{\displaystyle C_{1}} to objects of C2{\displaystyle C_{2}} and morphisms of C1{\displaystyle C_{1}} to morphisms of C2{\displaystyle C_{2}} in such a way that sources are mapped to sources and targets are mapped to targets (or, in the case of a contravariant functor, sources are mapped to targets and vice-versa). A third fundamental concept is a natural transformation that may be viewed as a morphism of functors.

Comedy writing is the process of creating jokes and comedic material. A comedian will often start by coming up with an idea or concept for a joke, and then they will brainstorm different ways to turn that idea into a funny joke or story. They might start by writing down their ideas in a notebook, or they might talk through their ideas with a friend or fellow comedian to get feedback and help them develop their ideas further. Once they have a strong idea, the comedian will then work on crafting the joke or bit, experimenting with different word choices and delivery methods to make the joke as funny as possible. This process can take a lot of trial and error, as the comedian will often need to try out different versions of the joke in front of an audience to see what works and what doesn't.

The first official flag of the United States, commonly known as the "Stars and Stripes," had 13 white, five-pointed stars arranged in a circular pattern on a blue field, with 13 red and white horizontal stripes. The stars represented the 13 original colonies that declared independence from Great Britain and became the first states in the Union. The red and white stripes represented the unity of the colonies. The design of the flag has evolved over the years, and today, the U.S. flag has 50 white, five-pointed stars on a blue field, with 13 horizontal red and white stripes. The stars represent the 50 states in the Union, and the stripes represent the original 13 colonies.

When we think, our brains are processing and organizing information. Our brains are made up of billions of tiny cells called neurons, which communicate with each other through electrical and chemical signals. When we think about something, our neurons send messages back and forth to each other very quickly, forming patterns and connections that help us understand and remember things.As for why we "feel" our thoughts in our head, it's because that's where our brain is located. Our brain is the organ that controls all of our thoughts and actions, so it makes sense that we would feel those things happening in our head. Our feet and other parts of our body don't play a direct role in thinking and processing information, so we don't typically feel those things happening there.

a spinal cord injury.One way that mirrors can be used to help with phantom limb syndrome is through a treatment called mirror therapy. In mirror therapy, a person sits in front of a mirror and moves their healthy limb. At the same time, they imagine moving their phantom limb. The reflection of the healthy limb in the mirror creates the illusion that the phantom limb is also moving. This can help to reduce the sensation of pain in the phantom limb.It's important to note that mirror therapy is just one treatment option for phantom limb syndrome and it may not work for everyone. Other treatments, such as medication and physical therapy, may also be helpful in managing the pain and discomfort associated with this condition.

" Fire " is the result of a substance reacting with oxygen and giving off chemical energy . For example , when hydrogen is ignited , hydrogen gas molecules , which are composed of two hydrogen atoms bonded together , break their bond to bond instead with oxygen molecules . This reaction turns the hydrogen gas and oxygen into water vapour and excess chemical energy which is observed as heat and light . The same goes for any other matter that forms a stronger bond to oxy gen than its existing bond . Also , helium is not flammable .

For solid objects the other answers are correct . For liquids it 's different , which I why it 's not the same to blow on the side of the cup of coffee or on the surface of the coffee . The liquid has an average temperature , but atoms individual energy will vary , some are colder and stay in liquid firm others are hotter and are in vapor . When you blow on the surface you eliminate the hotter atoms and leave the cooler atoms . But that does n't affect it much ... What 's more important is that the whole mass of the hot liquid is constantly trying to evaporate but only has a small surface area to do so ( I do n't think the ripples help massively ) so the air right above the coffee gets saturated with hot humid vapor and no more water can evaporate . This is called vapor pressure ( URL_0 ) . When you blow on it you remove this pocket and bring in new air ready to take in heated vapor thereby lowering the temperature of the liquid .

When you visit a web page , you 're looking at a collection of computer code that tells a web browser how to structure and style the content . These languages can include : HTML ( Hypertext Markup Language - generally structure ) CSS ( Cascading Style Sheets - generally for styling and the look & feel ) Javascript , Flash / ActionScript etc , mostly for interactivity ... A web browser takes all these languages , and decides how to display them to you . Now , this should be easy , but each browser actually has their own specific way of deciding how to display what . There are efforts to decide what is standard - and web pages can strive towards standards compliance , but the fact is some browsers ( especially older ones ) either do n't interpret , mis - interpret or just plain misunderstand some pieces of code . IE , Chrome , Firefox , Safari , Opera ... they all have their own little idiosyncrasies . Tor (short for The Onion Router) is a free, open-source network of servers that allows users to browse the internet anonymously. When you use Tor, your internet traffic is routed through a series of servers, or "nodes," that are run by volunteers all around the world. This makes it difficult for anyone to track your online activity or see your real IP address. Many people use Tor to protect their privacy and security online, especially when they are communicating sensitive information or accessing websites that might be blocked in their country. For example, journalists, activists, and whistle-blowers might use Tor to communicate with each other and share information without fear of being monitored or censored by their governments. However, it is possible for the Tor network to be

in the network, or by government agencies who are able to monitor traffic on the network. If this happens, it could potentially allow someone to see the activity of users on the Tor network and potentially even identify them. Eric Eoin Marques was arrested in 2013 on suspicion of operating a "hidden service" on the Tor network that was used to host child pornography. Marques was charged with several crimes related to child pornography and is currently awaiting trial in the United States. It is not clear how Marques was caught or how the authorities were able to identify him, but it is possible that the Tor network was compromised in some way.

A group of deer is typically called a herd. Deer are social animals and tend to live in herds, which can consist of a few individuals or many dozens of deer, depending on the species and habitat. The size of a deer herd can vary throughout the year, as deer tend to form larger herds during the winter months when food is scarce and smaller groups during the rest of the year when food is more abundant. Within a herd, deer often form complex social hierarchies, with dominant individuals leading the way and making important decisions for the group.

in a world that has been destroyed by some unknown disaster. The movie is about how our actions can have an impact on the world and the people around us, and how the events of the past can shape the future.

For those that do n't want to read the wiki article , the Friendship paradox is " most people have fewer friends than their friends do , on average " . For example , let 's take 5 people , Al , Betty , Carl , Don , and Elvira . Al is friends with everybody , but everyone else is only friends with Al . ( i.e. Carl and Don are not friends ) . Al has 4 friends , everyone else has 1 . It seems odd , but all of Betty 's friends have more friends than her , all of Carl 's friends have more friends than him , all of Don 's friends have more friends than him , and all of Elvira 's friends have more friends than her . The general reason this happens is because of social hubs like Al . Al is friends with lots of people ( maybe he 's just a friendly guy ) , so he makes the average of " friends of my friends " shoot way up . Also , unsurprisingly , since in knows so many people some of those people will only have a few friends . It 's surprising because most people think they are better than others , and therefore think they will have more friend , but this is rarely true .

It 's not that the body evolved to need a well balanced diet- we humans can survive on pretty unbalanced food just fine . What a well balanced diet is is that we have discovered that certain food combinations optimize the nutrients that out body gets . Think of your body like a car , food is fuel , you can put pretty much any gasoline in your car as fuel . But , you know , some gasoline works better in your car than others , some leaves buildups that make the car run worse , some contain additives that help keep the engine cleaner , and there are different octane levels that , while they can all technically burn in your car , often there is one specific one that is best suited to being used . TL;DR : your body can get by on a lot of things , and the well balanced diet is less a requirement of your body than the result of a lot of trial and error trying to figure out what is most optimal to eat .

Yes, it is generally a good idea to keep copies of your business's invoices for tax records. Invoices are an important source of information for your business and can be used to support various tax deductions and credits that your business may be eligible for. In addition, invoices can help you track your business's income and expenses and provide a record of your business's financial transactions.In the United States, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) generally requires businesses to keep records of their income and expenses for at least three years. However, some records, such as those related to real estate or investments, may need to be kept for longer periods of time. It is a good idea to consult with a tax professional or refer to IRS guidelines to determine how long you should keep specific types of records.Invoices should be kept in a safe and organized manner, such as in a file cabinet or a digital folder. You may also want to consider creating a system for labeling and organizing your invoices, such as by date or type of transaction. This can make it easier to locate specific invoices when needed and ensure that your business's tax records are complete and accurate.

The first people on Earth probably did not learn to speak and understand each other overnight. It would have taken time for them to develop a way of communicating with one another using words and sounds. The process of creating a language would have been a gradual one, and it is likely that the first languages were very simple, with only a few words for things like food, water, and shelter. Over time, as people needed to communicate more complex ideas, their languages would have become more complex as well. It is also possible that different groups of people on Earth developed their own languages independently of one another. So, it is not accurate to say that someone "suddenly" made up a language, but rather that language developed over time as a way for people to communicate with one another.
